title: Recordings at Risk Applicant Q&A Webinar, January 26, 2026
description:
Presenters: Louisa Kwasigroch, Sharon Burney, Alyson Pope, Jane Larson, Lizzi Albert

Webinar Description
A recording of the January 26, 2026, Recordings at Risk Applicant Q&A Webinar for Cycle 13. Applications are due February 24, 2026. For more information, including frequently asked questions, step-by-step application guidelines, and sample applications, visit the program website: https://www.clir.org/recordings-at-risk 

Program Description
Recordings at Risk is a national regranting program administered by CLIR to support the preservation of rare and unique audio, audiovisual, and other time-based media of high scholarly value through digital reformatting. Generously funded by the Mellon Foundation since January 2017, the program will run thirteen competitions from 2017 to 2026 and will award a total of $8.75 million. Awards range from $10,000 to $60,000 and cover costs of preservation reformatting for fragile and/or obsolete time-based media content by qualified external service providers. Eligible media may include but are not necessarily limited to magnetic audio and video tape, grooved discs, wax cylinders, wire recordings, and film (with or without sound).

title: Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices Recipient Webinar, January 12, 2026
description:
A session for recipients of the 2025 Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices program provides an orientation to the administrative aspects of holding a Hidden Collections grant. Topics covered include an overview of CLIR and available resources, steps to request grant modifications, reporting guidelines, and ways to stay in touch. 

For more information, visit the program web pages: https://www.clir.org/hiddencollections/.

Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices is a grant competition administered by the Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR) to digitize rare and unique content stewarded by collecting organizations in the US and Canada. Launched in 2021, with the generous support of the Mellon Foundation, the program has awarded approximately $11.9 million to archives, historical societies, libraries, museums, and other collecting organizations to deepen public understanding of the histories of people of color and other communities and populations whose work, experiences, and perspectives have been insufficiently recognized or unattended. The program builds upon the foundation of the previous iteration, Digitizing Hidden Special Collections and Archives, which awarded over $24 million in digitization grants from 2016 to 2020.

title: DLF Forum 2025 Opening Plenary
description:
Dr. KáLyn Coghill

"Your Silence Will Not Protect You: A Clarion Call to Make Online Protection the Rule and NOT the Exception"

Oftentimes, we are told in professional spaces that we are to be seen and not heard, but with the uptick of online gender-based violence impacting the most marginalized, we cannot afford to be silent. In this talk, Dr. KáLyn Coghill will discuss the precaritization of online gender-based violence, how it impacts us all, and how we can take steps to protect not only others but ourselves. This is not a request nor is it a suggestion; it is a demand and a clarion call for us to prioritize the experiences of those battling gender-based violence online and use our tools, skills, and resources to mitigate these harms and protect them.

title: DLF Forum 2025 Closing Plenary
description:
Evan Weissman, Warm Cookies of the Revolution

"The Public Imagination: A Closing Ritual for Cultural Heritage Workers"

As stewards of memory and imagination, cultural heritage workers play a vital role in shaping how communities remember, resist, and rebuild. In this participatory closing plenary, Warm Cookies of the Revolution, a Denver-based civic arts organization, invites attendees to engage in an interactive ritual honoring the people, places, and ideals that sustain our work. Through creative reflection, storytelling, and a communal “commitment postcard” activity, participants will consider what from this year’s Forum they want to carry forward, what future librarians and technologists should know about the world we’re saving, and how collective rituals of hope can nurture our shared purpose.

title: CLIR Climate Resiliency Webinar. Session 6: Big Data and the Preservation Problem
description: Data managers, digital curators, and librarians responsible for reformatting and archiving digital collections face exponential growth in data storage, requiring significant energy use that feeds climate concerns. At the same time, librarians are stewards of knowledge, and digital libraries offer archives a way to share their collections with a broader audience. This panel addresses the conflicts and opportunities between climate issues and digital archives, including maintaining industry standards, such as those from the NDSA, that encourage multiple geographically distributed copies. This workshop will provide participants with an introduction to the scope of library data usage and offer case studies on how librarians and data managers are changing their approaches.

description:

Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices (DHC:AUV) Applicant Support Series

This is the fourth in a series of five support sessions offering guidance and advice to those preparing final applications for the Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices program. The strongest grant applications often include concise and complete explanations of need, providing detailed justifications for each budget line. title: 2025 DHC:AUV Applicant Support Series #3 - Assessing Collections & Designing a Digitization Plan
description:
Presenter: Timothy A. Barber
Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices (DHC:AUV) Applicant Support Series

This is the third in a series of five support sessions offering guidance and advice to those preparing final applications for the Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices program. In this support session, we talk about how best to identify materials for digitization, providing informed estimates for collections sizes when little information is available, describing them in your application, and making a strong case that digitization is the best next-step. We also discuss how to be sure you are designing a project that can be achieved within the structure of the program and sustained into the future. We offer guidance on the technical specifications reviewers look for in the most competitive applications and explain some industry-standards concerning long-term digital preservation and sustainability.
